title: Bio4Community
subtitle: Stress in our Community and Bodies

text: STRESS AND HEART ATTACKS:
Rakesh’s Story
CHAPTER 1: DEAUNDRE

Rakesh (Rah-kay-sh) sat in the small break room in the Amazon warehouse, fidgeting with his lunch. He smiled as he looked down at the small post-it note poking out from inside the crumpled brown bag that read “Good luck at work today, Dad!” He loved when his kids snuck him little notes in his lunch. They always knew how to make him smile. He wanted to give them a stable life so he worked 15-hour days and woke up early to make his kids breakfast before going to work. It was hard being a single dad.

Even though his kids were older and in 7th grade and high school, it still felt like all the world’s burdens were on his shoulders; but seeing them happy helped. Raising his kids on his own had been difficult ever since Sorayah (So-raa-yaa), his wife or… well…ex-wife, and him split up. That left little time for Rakesh (Rah-kay-sh) to destress and have “me” time. But it was worth it if it meant he could eventually be promoted to manager. A higher pay and more stable hours would mean more time with his kids. As he looked at the note, Rakesh remembered the conversation he had with his kids that morning.
Ajay (Uh-jay): Ugh. I just can’t study for this math test.
Zainab (Zay-nab): Just do it.
Ajay (Uh-jay): Okay, genius.
Zainab (Zay-nab): I know, I’m so helpful, right?
Rakesh: What’s going on? What’s the issue?
Ajay: Dad... I can’t focus in class. Ms. Ross will put the equations on the board and next thing I know she got to the answer but I just don’t know how.
Rakesh: Well, you need to pay more attention when she’s teaching! Math is important so you have to try harder. You kids have opportunities that I never had. You have to make use of them.
Zainab: Like what, appa (father in Tamil)?

Rakesh: You’re going to a good school, with good teachers, and you actually have a chance to learn, for free! You can get a degree and do what you want to do with your life here. I never got that in India. There, you have to pay for private school if you want a good education and you know our family couldn’t afford that…
Ajay: Wait. What did you want to be when you were younger?
Rakesh: I wanted to be an aerospace engineer since I was very young.
Zainab: What’s that?
Rakesh: It’s someone who designs planes.
Zainab: So why not just become that now?

Rakesh: No... My time for studying and all is done.. It’s your turn now. You need to study hard so that you can grow up and become what you want. That will make me the happiest. So you better go now and make sure you (Rakesh points to Ajay) study for that math test.
Ajay: Okay, dad. Fine.

Working for Amazon was never Rakesh’s first choice of career. Being an immigrant without a degree made it hard to find a job. It was even harder, because Rakesh’s ex-wife Sorayah (So-raa-yaa) was still back in India which meant Rakesh had to provide for their kids by himself.

Rakesh and Sorayah met in high school in India and were married soon after graduating. Sorayah was from Iran but had lived in India almost all her life. Soon after they were married, Rakesh and Sorayah had two little children for whom they wanted a better life. So, they decided to immigrate to America. Rakesh left India first with the children so that the kids could start school in America.

Sorayah was supposed to follow once her visa was approved by the U.S. Immigration Services. But, to their surprise, Sorayah’s visa application was denied because of a new rule that prevented people from muslim countries coming into the U.S. This meant Sorayah couldn’t immigrate to America because she had an Iranian passport. Even after all these years, Rakesh still had a lot of anger for the U.S. Immigration rules that broke up his family. Back in the lunchroom at work, Rakesh was zoning out, pushing the rice in his container around, when one of his co-workers, Nicole, came in.
Nicole: Hey. Did you hear about Deaundre?
Rakesh: No.What happened? Is everything alright?
Nicole: He had a heart attack while he was here. He’s at the hospital right now.
Rakesh: WHAT! WHEN? I just saw him clock in this morning and he looked fine!

Rakesh felt the concern and shock take over him. He and Deaundre have a lot in common. They both were the same age, had two kids, and both loved baseball. Deaundre was one of those guys who worked just as hard as everyone else but did it with a smile on his face. Rakesh decided to visit Deaundre at the hospital before work the next day, stopping at a local bodega to grab him a smiling bear wearing a fedora that kind of looked like him.

tiles.title: Rakesh Visits Deaundre at the Hospital

text: [“Knock knock,” Rakesh entered with the bear held up to his face. Deaundre still had that smile plastered on. The two of them sat and talked for a while. ]
Rakesh: Man, I am so glad to see you. How are you? I couldn’t believe it when I heard the news.

Deaundre: I couldn’t believe it either. One minute I was working, the next I felt like my chest was so heavy and tight. It’s a good thing I wasn’t alone. I heard they called the ambulance right away, otherwise I don’t know what woulda happened.
Rakesh: Did the doctors tell you what’s wrong? You look so healthy!
Deaundre: Yeah, the doc keeps saying I’m too stressed and it’s causing blockages or something like that in my blood vessels. Somethin’ about stress causing all this bad stuff.
[This caught Rakesh’s attention.]
Rakesh: “Wait. Your stress led to your heart attack?”

To say Rakesh was shocked was an understatement. He admitted that stress sometimes got to his head, he felt jittery and anxious like there were butterflies in his stomach. But he didn’t understand how something in his mind could affect his body. Stress only had mental symptoms… right? He wondered, how could stress cause blocked blood vessels?
Can you help him figure this out?
Discuss with your group--What do you think is the connection between stress and blocked blood vessels?
Continue reading to find out what happened next:
Rakesh left the hospital even more stressed. When he got home he did his best not to show his children how worried he was.
Zainab: Hi Appa! Ajay already made the rice - the curry is just heating up now.
Rakesh: Thanks, I’ll just wash my hands and come.
Ajay: Hurry up dad, I’m so hungry! Coach ran us SO HARD at track. You remember we have the track meet this weekend right? Are you coming?
Rakesh: Yes Ajay, you know I’m gonna try. It all depends on whether I can find someone to cover my shift.
Zainab: Ok everybody come, dinner’s ready. Ajay you better not take all the rotis this time. I don’t care how hungry you are!

After dinner, when the kids were cleaning the kitchen, Rakesh decided to do some research on his own. He googled “heart attack and stress”. One of the links that came up caught his eye. It was a video of some monkeys and it showed a blocked blood vessel, he decided to check it out. He clicked on the link: “The Effects of Stress on the Heart”
• Watch the video- EVIDENCE 1-The Effects of Stress on the Heart - in the Resource Library.
• Discuss the video with your group and together, answer the questions about the evidence in the Resource Library.

text: CHAPTER 2: PAATI’S BIRTHDAY

The video that Rakesh watched bugged him for the next two days. He just couldn’t get over the differences between the two monkey’s blood vessels! Through a little more googling, he discovered that it was cholesterol that was filling those blood vessels. That puzzled him, he thought cholesterol was in food. How would it end up stuck in the middle of the blood vessel? He also thought of Deaundre, was his artery filled with that gross stuff?

On Sunday afternoon he and the kids were going to their grandmother’s, or Paati’s as they called her, 80th birthday. His cousin Meera was hosting. She was one of his favorite people on this planet and one of the smartest he knew. She was a certified nutritionist so maybe she would know more about cholesterol?

At the party, Paati was so happy to see everyone. Rakesh’s children– Zainab and Ajay – gave their grandmother huge hugs and her eyes beamed with joy. Rakesh was so happy to see his mother doing well. The birthday party was wonderful. The whole family was having a great time, the food was delicious, and you could feel the love surrounding Paati. While they were all eating, one of his aunts - Lakshmi (luck-sh-mi) - came up to him to talk.
Lakshmi: Wow, look at how big the kids have gotten!
Rakesh: Yeah, chithi (aunt in Tamil) they get bigger and bigger every day.
Lakshmi: Must be hard raising them all on your own. So irresponsible of their mother to just leave them and stay in India…
Rakesh: No chithi, you know that’s not what happened.
Lakshmi: An amma (mother in Tamil) should be there to raise her kids.

Rakesh: They’re my kids too and she is there for them. Chithi, you know how hard it is to get a visa, the immigration rules are so unfair. It’s not her fault that she is from Iran. Now look at her, she is doing so well. She got a degree, she found a job…
Lakshmi: Then why did she go and marry someone else?
Rakesh: Chiti, it’s OK, she has found someone and is happy. The kids are also doing OK and so am I. We made this decision together and we are all OK.
Lakshmi: They must be missing their amma though.
Rakesh: Of course they do! But we talk to her everyday and she is still such a big part of their lives.
Paati: Lakshmi, leave him alone. Sorayah is a good mother.
Lakshmi: I was just worried about the children.
Paati: If you cared about them, then you wouldn’t insult their mother. Vaa (come in Tamil), I want to eat my cake.

Paati led everyone to the cake, singing along happily to their joyous birthday song, and blowing out her candles. Rakesh enjoyed his cake but chithi’s words left a bitter taste in his mouth. It is not like they did not try every possible option to get a visa, but it was just impossible with the many rules and expensive lawyer fees. Thinking about all of this - Rakesh could feel the stress butterflies in his stomach again. He quickly scanned the crowd for Meera and went up to her.

tiles.title: Rakesh Chatting with Meera at Paati's Party

text: Rakesh: Eh.. listen, Meera, I know you’re busy hosting right now, but I have a serious question I really need to ask you. My friend Deaundre had a heart attack this week and the doctor said it was caused by blocked blood vessels. I looked it up and saw that blood vessels were blocked by cholesterol or something. Do you know anything about this?

Meera: Oh god! That's scary. I hope your friend is okay. Yeah cholesterol is found in most foods and could cause blockages. I actually wrote about cholesterol and health in my blog a few weeks ago. Didn’t you see it in the family text group?
Rakesh: Wait. I didn’t know you have a blog! That’s awesome!
Meera: Well clearly you need to check the family group chat properly because I’ve sent many links from my blog for everyone to read!
[Meera laughed at Rakesh, who looked a bit sheepish and smiled. He definitely does not keep up with the family group chat and just got caught! Meera continued: ]
Meera: Honestly, I do it mostly for my clients. It saves so much time. I’ll text you the link for the post about cholesterol. Read that and then tell me what you think ok?
Rakesh: Absolutely! And this time, I promise I’ll actually read the what you send!
Meera: Aha.. sure whatever you say.. (Meera winked at Rakesh)

Rakesh laughed and was about to ask Meera more questions, but Paati was ready for tea and so Meera rushed to go get it ready for her. Once he got home from the party, Rakesh checked his phone and found the text from Meera. He clicked on the link she sent: “All the Fuss About Cholesterol”

text: CHAPTER 3: WHAT'S IN YOUR BLOOD

Rakesh read the blog and realized he really did need to start paying more attention to the family group text. Meera was amazing at explaining stuff and her blog was really interesting! Based on her post he believed that his diet was mostly fine. Every dinner the family ate was homecooked, and had food even his chithi would approve of. There was almost always a piece of fruit or a vegetable curry in his lunch.

Yet, he was still nervous about those blockages. If even babies have cholesterol, then was there was a chance that despite his healthy life habits he could still have too much cholesterol in his blood? The fear of his arteries getting clogged up was still not leaving him. He just couldn’t stop worrying about it no matter how hard he tried.

So he decided to just get his blood checked and confirm whether he had high cholesterol or not. He called the doctor’s office and they ordered some tests and told him to go to the blood lab. The next day he went to the lab right after work, did the blood test. Two days later he received an email from the lab, the results were attached. He clicked on the attachment: “Rakesh Sharma Blood Test Report”

text: CHAPTER 4: WHAT’S IN YOUR SALIVA

A few days later Rakesh went to the doctor’s discuss the results. Rakesh was not a fan of the doctor’s office. It always seemed so cold, and the waiting room was usually very crowded. Finally, the nurse took him to the exam room inside and he waited for a few minutes for the doctor to see him.

Dr. Adebayo (Ah-de-baa-yo): Nice to see you Mr. Sharma. I have the results of your test here and they look fine to me. I know you were concerned about your cholesterol levels, but they are well within range. I don’t think you need to do anything about it.
Let th impulse die in the middle: Oh, thank you Dr. Adebayo. That is such a relief to hear!
Dr. Adebayo (Ah-de-baa-yo): I’m glad! But Mr. Sharma, why were you concerned about your cholesterol in the first place?

Rakesh: A close friend of mine had a minor heart attack last week. His doctor said that his blood vessels were clogged, and I read that cholesterol can cause clogged arteries. So, I just wanted to make sure that my cholesterol levels are not something I need to worry about.
Dr. Adebayo: Ah yes, that’s true Mr. Sharma. High cholesterol can cause issues in your blood vessels, but stress has also been linked to heart attacks.

Rakesh: Right. I remember finding a video online that showed that stress can cause blocked blood vessels too. My friend and I have the same job and similar responsibilities and I am stressed a lot too….
[Rakesh didn’t finish his sentence and Dr. Adebayo could tell that Rakesh seemed to be getting worried again. ]

Dr. Adebayo: Listen Mr. Sharma, why don’t we order a test to measure your stress hormone levels? I can ask the nurse to administer the blood test before you leave today, and you will get the results in a week.”
[Rakesh still looked a bit worried but agreed and went to see the nurse.]

Once he got home, Rakesh was still feeling anxious about stress tests and decided to research it more after dinner. He googled ‘how to test for stress’ and found that there were many ways to measure cortisol levels. He noticed a video explaining how saliva (spit) can be used to measure cortisol levels easily and quickly. The website also had a link to order the test and get results within 24 hours. Out of restlessness, and not wanting to wait a whole week for his results from Dr. Adebayo, Rakesh decided to order a saliva stress test as well. The test arrived the next day, he followed the instructions and then mailed it back to the lab. As promised, within 24 hours, Rakesh got an email back from the lab with the results from his saliva test. His stomach was tight with nervousness as he opened the email: “Saliva Stress Test”.

text: CHAPTER 5: DR. ZEIDERS

Reading the test results and finding that his cortisol levels were too high, Rakesh could feel his chest tightening and hands sweating. He knew this was not good news, but he had no idea what to do about it. His thoughts raced and he started to feel dizzy. He closed his eyes and took several deep breaths to calm his body down. He thought about what he could do right now and decided to email the scientist in that video about saliva cortisol tests. Her name was Dr. Zeiders and her email was on the website. Rakesh emailed Dr. Zeiders:

Surprisingly, Dr. Zeiders responded to Rakesh’s email by the next day. She said that she would be happy to meet with Rakesh online to chat about the test results and what her lab has discovered about the link between stress, cortisol, and clogged arteries. She added that they have also created a simulator to explain the link. They set a time to meet over zoom. He was looking forward to his conversation with Dr. Zeiders.

text: Chapter 6: CHILDREN ARE THE FUTURE

A few minutes after finishing the zoom conversation with the scientist, Rakesh heard the front door opening. He could hear Zainab and Ajay throwing their backpacks onto the ground, taking off their shoes and running into the kitchen to make a snack for themselves. Rakesh went downstairs and joined them in the kitchen.

tiles.title: Rakesh in the Kitchen with Kabir and Ajay

text: Rakesh: So, what’d you kids do at school today?
Ajay: Nothing really. Senior year is kinda boring.
Rakesh: I’m sure there was at least one thing fun that happened at school today, no?
Zainab: We did a cool experiment in my science class!
Ajay: Of course you did Zainab. 7th grade is way more fun than senior year. You’re so lucky….I miss those good old days…
Zainab: Ugh why do you have to talk like some old uncle. You know you’re only 5 years older than me right? Jeez…
Rakesh: Okay now kids , be nice to each other! Zainab, what was the experiment about?
[Zainab stuck her tongue out at Ajay as though she had won the fight and then said,]

Zainab: Okay. So. In class, they showed us a graph about stress rates and I learned that black people have more stress because of racism. I also learned that because of stress you could get heart disease that can cause a heart attack . Look at this other graph, appa! [Zainab put the piece of paper on the kitchen table]. It shows that black people have more heart attacks! We learned that exercise is really good for you. It can make you feel happier and actually, dad, it can like lowers your stress also!
[Rakesh picked up the paper Zainab placed on the table. He looked at the graphs and thought to himself oh wow - maybe I need to tell Deaundre that he needs to start working out too…]
Rakesh: Wait. Really? Exercise can decrease stress?

Zainab: Yeah! I’m not kidding! Mrs. Edwards, our PE teacher, also told us about how recess is really important for us. Because like all day we’re sitting in class. And so in recess we get a chance to exercise and lower our stress.
Rakesh: Oh wow, that’s amazing! I had no idea!
Ajay: Come on, really, dad? You’re not just making Zainab feel good right?
Rakesh: No, I’m being serious! You kids teach me things all the time!

Rakesh loved learning from his kids. He decided to give what his daughter said a try and started to incorporate exercise into his daily routine. He may not have been lifting heavy weights, but even going for a jog in the morning before making the kids’ breakfast felt really good. After his jogs, he always felt a little lighter, like the weight on his shoulders had lifted a bit. The more he exercised, the better he started to feel. However, he was often still stressed by the end of the day.
The End!
• Use your evidence table to develop a model that shows how long-term stress can result in clogged blood vessels.

text: STRESS AND FOCUS:
Estrella’s Story
CHAPTER I: MATH TEST

Estrella loved her family very much. She would go to the ends of the earth for them and knew that they would do the same for her. Her mom and step-dad worked long hours everyday to put a roof over their head. Estrella’s abuela (grandma) stayed home and watched over the kids. Abuela did a lot for them but sometimes it got hard for her to take care of so many things, so Estrella took it upon herself to help out.

Estrella often dropped off and picked up her younger brothers and sister from their school bus stop and they would tell her everything that happened during their day with bright eyes and wide smiles. Once they got home Estrella would spend the afternoon making sure her siblings did their homework and daily chores, and then she walked the family dog before dinner. Estrella also made time for her two best friends in the evenings when they played online together. This meant most days Estrella stayed up until midnight to get her work done. Sometimes she was so tired she wished she could just go to sleep, but her grades were important to her and she was doing well in school.

However, in school she often had trouble focusing. She really did want to focus in class, but sometimes the teacher’s voice became nothing but white noise and Estrella would zone out. She needed to be able to pay attention in class if she wanted to stay in honors math even though her best friends were in the lower level general math.

One day after school, Estrella felt like she was dragging her body home because she was so upset. That morning she was late to school - again - because her siblings’ school bus didn’t come on time. As per the school rules, she had to get a tardy-note from the main office that made her even more late for math. The class was taking a math test and she had missed the first 10 minutes but was still expected to finish it on time like everyone else. In addition to being late, Estrella found she just couldn’t focus. She found herself staring at the paper and the numbers were glaring back at her, making no sense. She had the sinking feeling that she didn’t do well on the test. On the way home, her siblings just would not listen to her. They were almost to the front of their house when they started fooling around.
Paco: Tito, watch me do a handstand.
Tito: Whatever. I bet you can’t run as fast as me
Paco: Bet I can!
Sandra: Hermana (sister), I wanna run too!
Estrella: No running, it’s the street. we have to go home.
Tito: Catch me if you can!
Sandra: Me too! Me too!
Estrella: STOP RUNNING! What are you doing?
[Estrella grabs her siblings by the back of their shirts]
Estrella: Why do you never listen to me? STOP fooling around!
Her siblings were shocked by the snap in her tone. Sandra began to cry, and ran into the house and straight to Abuela.
Abuela: Nena, ¿Por qué estás llorando? (Baby girl, why are you crying?)
Sandra: She screamed at me!
Estrella: I did not! You weren’t listening to me and were about to run out into the street.
Tito: We were not!
Abuela: Estrella, they’re little. You’re older, be patient with them.
Estrella: You’re never on my side! You always choose them over me.
Abuela: Estrella, Mija (daughter), that’s not true. I am on your side. What’s going on with you, Nena (baby girl)?
Estrella: Es nada (it's nothing), Abuela.
Abuela: Ay. I know you too well for that. I can tell something is bothering you.
Estrella: Well… I was late to school, missed half of math class, and didn’t do well on the test.
Abuela: But you normally do so well. What happened?
Estrella: I don’t know. Sometimes I can’t focus in class. I’m just so tired and I think of everything else in the world. I try to focus, I really do. But, I just can’t.
Estrella choked back tears, trying to hide how upset she was. She felt as though no matter how hard she tried, her efforts were useless.

Abuela: Mi corazón (my heart), you’re tired. Of course you can’t focus. You’re stressed and sleep deprived. I’ve been telling you it’s not good to stay up till midnight so often. Why don’t you talk to your school counselor about how you feel? Aren’t you close with your science teacher? Maybe talk to her. I’m sure they’ll understand and try to help you.
Estrella: I just feel like I don’t even belong in these classes.
Abuela: Why would you say that? Of course you do.
Estrella: It’s just… I remember Ms. Parker telling me that I don’t.
Abuela: What? When?
~~ FLASHBACK ~~
[Ms. Parker was handing back the math tests for honors Calculus. This one was particularly hard and Estrella knew she didn’t do as well as she would have liked.]
Ms. Parker: Estrella, can I talk to you for a second?
Estrella: Y-yes, of course.
Ms. Parker: I noticed that you haven’t been doing well on your tests lately. I talked to the school counselor and we think it might be best if you dropped down to the easier general level math class.
Estrella: Why? I like math….

Ms. Parker: I’m just saying it might be better for you. Honors classes are difficult as it is and I don’t think you really need it anyway. People in your neighborhood don’t usually go to college so why waste your time. Might as well enjoy high school instead of struggling so much.
Estrella: O-oh.
~~ END FLASHBACK ~~
Abuela: Estrella. Do not listen to her!!
Estrella: What if she’s right, Abuela?
Abuela: She is not and you know it! You know you are going to universidad (university).

Estrella knew her grandma was usually right about these things. She had never considered that maybe what she was feeling inside, the tense muscles and racing heartbeat, could be stress. Or that stress could be the reason she couldn’t focus. Estrella decided to talk to her science teacher after school tomorrow.
Do you think Abuela is right?
Discuss with your group--What do you think is the connection between stress and focus?

text: CHAPTER 2: LEARNING FROM MS. GUERRA
The next day after science class, Estrella stayed behind and spoke with her science teacher, Ms. Guerra.
Estrella: Hi Ms. Guerra, can I talk to you for a moment?
Ms. Guerra: Of course, Estrella. What do you need?
Estrella: I’ve been having a lot of issues with focusing lately and it's been hurting my grades.
Ms. Guerra: Oh Estrella! It is ok. High school can be a really tough time. I know you’re involved in a lot of activities and you’re so helpful at home too.
Estrella: Yeah… I was wondering if you could explain to me some science about attention and stress?
Ms. Guerra: Oh of course. Your brain is a really complicated organ and spends your whole life processing so much information. When we feel stressed it can get harder for us to focus on things.
Estrella: That makes sense….
Ms. Guerra: Remember earlier in the year we talked about neurons.
Estrella: I think so. Aren't neurons the cells in your brain that send signals to each other?
Ms. Guerra: Yes! If your issue is being able to focus, you need to work on growing more connections between the neurons in your brain!

Estrella didn’t really understand what that meant and Ms. Guerra could sense her confusion. Figuring Estrella needed more of an explanation, Ms. Guerra pulled out a video that she had used when she taught college courses a few years ago. Huddled around the computer, the two of them clicked on the link: “How our Brains Think”
• Watch the slide show- EVIDENCE 1-How our Brains Think - in the Resource Library.

text: CHAPTER 3: MAKING CONNECTIONS

After watching the video, Estrella now understood that in order to focus better, the signaling between neurons needed to get stronger. Her neurons simply needed to make more connections! It seemed that maybe stress had nothing to do with her inability to focus, after all.

The next week in school, Estrella tried to practice focusing harder. Every time she was in class and caught herself feeling distracted she just thought about her neurons and concentrated as hard as she could to encourage them to make new connections. But despite her best efforts, it didn’t seem to work. She still could not focus. That evening while having dinner her mother asked her:
Mamá: Mija, como estan sus hermanos? Ellos comieron? (Daughter, how are your brothers? Did they eat?)
Estrella: Si, nosotros comimos. (Yes, we ate)
Mamá: Bien, ayudarles con sus tareas, ok? (Good, help them with their homework, ok?)
Estrella: Ok, Mama.
Papá: Paco y Tito tienen una conferencia con las maestras en una semana, verdad? (Paco and Tito have a conference with the teachers in a week, right?)
Estrella: Sï (Yes)
Mamá: Tú necesitas venir con nosotros para hablar con las maestras en inglés. (You need to come with us to talk to the teacher in English)
Estrella: Pero, yo tengo una examen y necesito estudiar. (But, I have an exam and I need to study)

Papá: Estrella, tú sabes que no hay conferencias de maestras en español. No entenderemos sin tu ayuda. Esto es muy importante para Tito y Paco, piensa en ellos también. (Estrella, you know that there are no conferences for teachers in Spanish. We won’t understand without your help. This is very important for Tito and Paco, think of them)
Estrella: Okay…

Estrella felt like she had so many things piling up on her plate, her shoulders felt heavier and heavier with each task. All this made focusing even harder. Feeling frustrated, Estrella decided to look up “brain, stress, and neuron signaling” on Google. A few links down from the top, she came across a blog post: “Stress and the Brain”.
• Read the blog- EVIDENCE 2-Stress and the Brain - in the Resource Library.

text: CHAPTER 4: IT’S ALL ABOUT THE NETWORKS

After going through the blog, Estrella began to understand that stress hormones were blocking her ability to pay attention. Who knew something in your brain could stop you from focusing? If stress hormones were stopping her from focusing, what else could they do? Her mind seemed fixated on these scary thoughts and she felt anxious and unsettled. She decided to visit Ms. Guerra again tomorrow.

Estrella didn’t have science the next day, so she waited till the end of the day to walk over to Ms. Guerra’s room. When she got there, Ms. Guerra was cleaning the classroom so Estella helped with the cleaning.
Estrella: Remember my question a few days ago about stress, Ms. Guerra?
Ms. Guerra: Yeah I do. Did you look into that more?
Estrella: I did actually. Yesterday, I was thinking about how my stress may be related to my focusing so I googled up stress and neuron signaling.
Ms. Guerra: That’s really smart Estrella. What did you find out?
Estrella: I found this really cool blog post by this scientist. Her name is Dr. Mackey? I think.
Ms. Guerra: Oh that’s awesome.
[Ms. Guerra stopped what she was doing, and thought for a moment.]

Ms. Guerra: You know it seems like you’re really interested in this topic, and spending a lot of time on it. Do you want to do a project about stress and focus for your science honors project this year?
Estrella: I.. I can do that? But.. I already tried to look online and I couldn’t find much more…it’s all really confusing
Ms. Guerra: Oh don’t worry Estrella. Why don’t I email the scientist, Dr. ...
Estrella: Dr. Mackey?
Ms. Guerra: Yes. Dr. Mackey! And I’ll ask her for some helpful resources for you.
Estrella: Wow.. you’re gonna email a real scientist?
Ms. Guerra: Why not! Let’s see what happens!

text: CHAPTER 5: SLEEP AND MOTIVATION

The project and research helped Estrella understand that the stress hormones caused her brain to think differently, with her fear networks having stronger connections than the neuron networks that help her pay attention and focus. While interesting to learn, Estrella was trying to figure out how to deal with these stress hormones so that she could build stronger attention networks. As she thought about all this, Estrella had a realization.

Her lack of focus seemed to happen only at school! She had no trouble focusing when she was helping her siblings with their homework or playing video games with her friends! Why would the stress hormones only affect her at school and then stop affecting her when she got home? Estrella decided these questions were worth one more trip to Ms. Guerra after school. She needed to solve this puzzle once and for all! Ms. Guerra thought Estrella’s question was a really good one. She herself did not have an answer so they decided to email Dr. Mackey again and ask.

text: CHAPTER 6: FINDING SOLUTIONS TOGETHER
After reading the email, Estrella smiled to herself. Abuela was right - she always was. Estrella was so excited she had to share the news with Abuela. She thanked Ms. Guerra and rushed home.
Estrella: ¡Abuela! ¡Abuela! ¡Abuela! [Grandma, Grandma, Grandma]
Abuela: ¡Sí! ¡Sí! ¡Sí! [Yes, Yes, Yes]
Estrella: I have to tell you something. I learned some stuff about my focus problem.

Estrella energetically filled her grandmother in on her breakthrough. She barely took breaths between sentences, her words running into each other. Her grandmother listened intently and when Estrella was done she told her that this was important information that the whole family should hear and talk about at dinner. That night, as Estrella, Abuela, Papá, Mamá, and Estrella’s younger siblings - Tito, Paco and Sandra - were sitting around the table, Estrella carefully explained to them everything she learned.
Estrella: So that’s why I’m not focused during school. I’m not motivated by it even though I want to do well.
Estrella: Wow, you learned all that and you worked so hard to learn it. Good job, mija [daughter].
Tito: Wh-what’s motiwasion?
[Estrella giggled at her youngest brother’s pronunciation.]
Papá: It’s like when you manage to somehow climb onto the cabinet when you want a cookie but can’t climb into bed when it’s bedtime. The cookie is your motivation.
Paco: So hermana (sister) just needs a cookie?
Mamá: A cookie helps, but maybe you should also talk to your teachers about making school more motivating to learn.
Estrella: I like that idea Mamá. I’m worried about talking to Ms. Parker for honors Calculus because she doesn’t think I’m smart enough for that class…but I can talk to Ms. Guerra for Science.
Abuela: I think we all need to get to sleep earlier too. Pobrecitos are always dragging their heads in the morning going to school.
Papá: I wouldn’t mind a few extra minutes of shut eye.
Sandra: Papá, you fall asleep the earliest!
[The whole family burst into laughter.]

That night Estrella went to bed an hour earlier. She did feel more rested the next day. She was also looking forward to talking with Ms. Guerra about stress, motivation, and school work. Ms. Guerra was a great teacher, she would probably have some good ideas to make science more interesting, relevant, and motivating to learn. Estrella hopes that Ms. Guerra might also give her some advice on how to talk to Ms. Parker about helping her stay motivated in honors Calculus.
The end!
• Use your evidence table to develop a model that shows how long-term stress can result in difficulty in focusing.

text: STRESS AND FEELING SICK:
Felix’s Story
CHAPTER 1: A NEW PHASE IN LIFE

Being a law student is hard work, especially for Felix who just started his final year of law school. He loved the independence that came with life in his mid 20s. He got to choose his own classes, meet new people, and finally got to live with his boyfriend, Josué. Moving out of his parents’ home and into an apartment with Josué was so exciting, it was a dream come true even though all they could afford was a tiny basement apartment that was old and pretty run down. At the same time, law school life also meant that he had to pay for his college fees, course textbooks, and of course, rent and groceries! Moving away from home, living with his boyfriend, and starting this new phase in his life meant he had new responsibilities and more expenses.

To pay his living expenses, Felix worked at the grocery store close to his apartment. He would plan his shifts around his classes and try to get as many as he could. Some days he would have a full day of classes and then pick up two shifts right after, then go home and stay up all night reading for his classes the next day. Josué always worried about how hard Felix worked. One night, when Felix had just worked for six hours straight and was starting on his homework, Josué decided to say something about it.
Josué: Mi amor (my love), it’s 1:00 am. You need to sleep or else you’re gonna collapse during class.
Felix: Yo sé pero, (I know but) I have to finish this assignment. I’ll go to bed soon.
Josué: You say that every night.
Felix: Ya vengo (I’ll come). I promise.

Felix didn’t want to admit it, but he knew Josué was right. But what was he supposed to do? How was he supposed to pay for rent if he didn’t work? After reading for another 30 minutes, Felix decided to listen to Josué and go to bed.

The next morning Felix woke up with a stuffy nose and a slight cough. He thought about maybe not going to his classes and resting. But then he remembered that he had to give a presentation that he couldn’t miss. And then he had another double shift at work. He wished the grocery store gave part-time employees sick days too. He was getting sick more often and it was really starting to make life harder. Felix and Josué couldn’t afford health insurance which meant they never saw the doctor even if they needed to. He decided to call his mom in hopes she would be able to provide him some tips and home remedies to help him get better.
Felix: Hola Mamá. Está bien? (Are you well?)
Mamá: Sí Felix. Qué te pasa? (Whats wrong?)
Felix: I’m just feeling a little under the weather lately. What do I eat to stop coughing again?
Mamá: I don’t think I can help you. You know what you have to change to stop being sick.
Felix: W-what do you mean?
Mamá: Well, you choose to live that lifestyle. Of course you’re going to get sick and stressed. Leaving your family and living with another man, what did you think was going to happen?
Felix: You think I’m getting sick because I’m gay? I didn’t CHOOSE any lifestyle. I can’t help who I love.
Mamá: Did you call me to argue?
Felix: I called you looking for some help and comfort while I was sick, like I did when I was little. Clearly that was a mistake.

Felix hangs up the phone without hearing his mom’s response. He doesn’t know why he tries when he knows how his family is. Ever since he came out to them, they have been the opposite of supportive. If Felix’s head didn’t already hurt before, it for sure hurt after that phone call. It left him with a bitter taste in his mouth and a heavy feeling in his chest. Felix shook his head. He had other things to worry about aside from his mom’s homophobia. Lying in bed, Felix realized there was no way he could take the day off to recover. Instead, he just popped cough drops in his mouth and tried to deal with it. Felix walked into the kitchen to find Josué had already made coffee for them, and was just starting to pack their lunches.
Felix: Good morning mi amor… (Felix coughs)
Josué: Don’t tell me. You’re sick. Again?? Mi amor, c’mon now you know this isn’t right. I’m telling you, you’re stressing yourself to the point where you’re getting sick.
Felix: Ugh please don’t. Not so early in the morning. I’m fine. And don’t be ridiculous, stress doesn’t make you sick.
Josué knew he was right, but didn’t know how to make Felix hear him. As usual, Felix was just being so stubborn, and now Josué needed to find a way to get through to him.
Do you think Josué is right?
Discuss with your group--What do you think is the connection between stress and getting sick often?
Continue reading to find out what happened next:
When he finished packing their lunches, Josué looked up and noticed Felix seemed upset.
Josué: You seem down. What’s wrong?
Felix: Oh nothing. I just called my mom asking her for some advice on treating this annoying cough.
Josué: Oh no… what did she say this time? Did she give you any actual advice?
Felix: Nope. She essentially said I’m sick because I’m gay.
Josué: Well… what did you expect? I’m sorry love…

Felix: I know. I just wanted some comfort from my mom, ya know? Jeez it’s the 21st Century and being gay isn’t illegal.. I don’t know why my mom and our community have these ridiculous expectations that everyone has to be straight. And now I feel like I'm never gonna get that love and comfort from my family again.

Josué: You need to give them time, my love. In time, they’ll see what they’re missing out on and maybe you can have an actual conversation with them. But until then, you have my parents, no? And they love you so much!
Felix: Thanks Josué.
Josué: In fact, you know what. I think you should call my mom right now. She’s a doctor and a mom so she knows a lot about people getting sick.

Felix reluctantly agreed and figured a chat with Josué’s mom wasn’t that hard to do. Josué, realizing he had a golden opportunity, pulled out his phone right away and rang his mother. Josué’s mother picked up the phone and Josué loudly told her that Felix was sick again! Unfortunately, Josué’s mom was in the middle of seeing a patient and couldn’t talk. She told them that she would send them a link to a slide show that explains how and why you get sick. Later that day, Felix was in class when he saw a text from Josué’s mother with a link to the slide show. He couldn’t wait so he clicked on the link: “How Do You Get Sick?”
• Watch the slide show- EVIDENCE 1-How Do You Get Sick? - in the Resource Library.

text: CHAPTER 2: HEALTHY JOSUÉ

After watching the slide show, Felix realized that he was getting sick because his body was trying to fight germs. He was right after all! And Josué’s mother helped support Felix’s case! It was not because he was stressed after all! That night when he got home from work, Felix called out to Josué.

Felix: Mi amor, guess what I found out today? I looked at those slides your mom sent, and, I was RIGHT! I’m just fighting off germs that are trying to get into my body! Stress has nothing to do with this!
Josué: Oh yeah, really? That’s what my mom’s thing really said? [Felix nodded and Josué thought for moment…]
Josué: But wait. One second. If it’s just germs and not stress, then why am I not getting sick?
Felix: Huh? What d’u mean?
Josué: We live together, you’d think I would be sick as often as you, sí?

This made Felix pause. He thought about it and realized that his boyfriend might actually have a point. Germs do travel from one person to the other, especially when someone coughs or sneezes - which Felix does a lot. And it’s true, Felix couldn’t even remember the last time Josué was sick. While he was thinking about this, Josué had already pulled out his phone and was looking up “stress and being sick” on YouTube. After a bit of searching, Josué found a good video. He called Felix over and clicked on the video: “Stress and Sickness”

text: CHAPTER 3: MOVIE NIGHT

Felix thought about the video and had to admit it worried him a bit. Maybe he really was getting sick because of stress? But how? And was he really stressed that much? Enough to make him sick? Ugh, was Josué actually right?

Felix made his way over to the school library to study for an exam that was coming up soon. This class was one of his pre-Law classes so it was important and the professor was known to be strict with grading. It was fair to say Felix was stressed about this exam and knew there were a lot of things he had to study still. But, no matter how hard he stared at the textbook, he couldn’t focus. The words were blurring together and his thoughts were getting in the way.
Felix thought to himself as he read the textbook --

Okay so the government had established laws regarding immigration… uhh my head hurts so much. none of this makes sense. Ok FOCUS. I only have three days to cover 7 chapters. If I get through the harder chapters today, maybe tomorrow can just be review. But I can’t focus… My body feels so weak.

Felix kept trying to read the same paragraph over and over again. At some point, he must have fallen asleep. Next thing he knew, he woke up and it was 2 hours later. He rushed to the bathroom to splash water on his face and noticed the lines of the book imprinted onto his face. Well. That’s one way of taking in the information, he thought to himself. By the time Felix got home from the library, Josué could practically see the stress rolling off him.
Josué: Felix. You look dead on your feet.
Felix: It’s fine, I got through the chapters I had to for the exam.
Josué: Your body is screaming from the stress, I can hear it. You watched the video about stress and getting sick, right? Remember that?
Felix: I know, I know. I just really need to do well on this exam.
Josué: Okay but know that you have already studied so much, you need a break. I think we both do.
Felix: Fine…Maybe you’re right.

Being around their community and friends usually helped them feel better and so they decided to go to the movie night that the LGBTQ+ club on campus hosts every Friday. There were always good snacks, cool friends and an entertaining movie to watch. Today, they ran into their friend Camila, who they hadn’t seen for quite a while.

tiles.title: Felix, Josue and Camila at Movie Night

text: Camila: Felix! Josué! How are you! How has everything been? It’s been so long. Where you two been hiding?
Felix: It’s good, I feel good! Girl, you look fantastic!
[Camila was just about to hug Felix, when he sneezed. This earned him a disappointed look from Josué. Camila gave Josué a questioning look.]
Josué: What he’s not mentioning is that he’s been working so hard his stress is making him sick.
Camila: What?
Felix: Is not. Camila. Josué is just being dramatic.
[As if on cue, Felix sneezed again.]
Josué: Ay Dios mío [Oh my God], yes it can! Stop fighting with me about this!
Camila: Okay, listen. I don’t know what this whole argument is about. But Felix, if you’re feeling stressed why don’t you just get a stress test? That way you’ll know if Josué is right or not!
Felix: A what?
Camila: A stress test! All you have to do is go to a clinic near you. They have a program for people who don’t have health insurance and you can tell them you need to get your stress levels tested.
Felix: We don’t have anything near us - not a clinic, not a bank, even the grocery store is so bad.. Remember where we live?
Camila: Oh yeah, I forgot how unfortunate that part of town is.
Josué: Excuse me? Unfortunate?
Felix: Camila, you used to live there too. Just cause your parents got fancy jobs and bought a house in the suburbs with all the rich white people….Don’t forget your roots.

Camila: Yeah.... I know. I’m not forgetting my roots, okay? It’s obviously weird not seeing any black or brown people like us around. And I know it’s not fair at all, but do you know how easy it is for me to get to a clinic or the nice grocery store from my house now?
Felix: (getting irritated) Hey, at least when we get home late at night, our neighbors don’t call the cops on us cause they think we don’t belong there!

Josué: Exactly. Sure you guys moved out and live in a more fancy area, but we still have the best taqueria and Señor Sanchez still lets us take the chili mango candies for free when we go to his bodega. We have a community of people that look out for each other.
Camila: Yeah, you’re right I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to come off rude. I haven’t had a good birria [meat] taco in such a long time, I think it’s getting to my head.
Felix: Well come over and we can change that. (Felix playfully nudges Camila.)
Camile: I would love that. And really, I’m sorry about what I said... But Felix, you should still look for somewhere to get a stress test and then you can finally prove who is right.

Josué and Felix looked at each other briefly before nodding in agreement! Before the test, Felix decided he needed to know more about what this stress test was going to involve. So, he searched and found a video on how stress test works. He clicked the link: “Saliva Stress Test” and watched the short video. The test seemed simple enough. He went to the clinic the next day and did the test himself. Within two days the results came in! Felix opened the email with bated breath, eager to see who was right. He clicked on the attachment: “Saliva Stress Test”, and he and Josué read the results.

text: CHAPTER 4: PROFESSOR NASSIR
As he read the report, Felix’s heart was racing, how stressed was he? Is Josué right about him? The test showed that his cortisol levels were way too high. He was, in fact, very stressed.
Josué: Mi vida (my world), I didn’t want to be right. I’m so worried.
Felix: Yo sé (I know). I didn’t think I was that stressed and it could be making me sick.

Knowing about his cortisol levels made Felix feel even more anxious. What could he do? He realized he could reach out to his immunology professor from undergrad. Professor Nassir was one of the best professors Felix had in college. She was always so helpful with any of his questions and cared about her students a lot. She would know how to interpret this and wouldn’t mind him asking her for help. Her office hours were every Thursday from 1:00 - 3:00 pm so he emailed her letting her know he would be dropping in. At 2:30, Felix found Professor Nassir getting ready to leave. He knocked on the office door:
Felix: Hi, Professor Nassir, how are you?
Prof. Nassir: Hey Felix! It’s so wonderful to see you! Aren’t you in law school now? What brings you here?
Felix: Yes, yes, I am. Law school is going really well, but I’ve been struggling a bit with my health and I had a biology-related question that I was hoping you may be able to help me figure out.
Prof. Nassir: Sure, of course, what is it?

Felix: OK. Well, I’ve been getting sick a lot lately and I think it may be because I’m stressed. I took a stress test and found out my cortisol levels are too high. But I don’t understand how cortisol could make me sick, I just don’t get the connection.

Prof. Nassir: Oh Felix, I’m sorry to hear about your stress levels. Balancing college, work, family, and friends is really difficult. You have always been such a good student so I know you must be working hard.
Felix: Thank you, I’m doing OK. It is super hard right now, I had several assignments due this week including a huge presentation that I gave the other day.

Prof. Nassir: That sounds like a lot, you really need to take time for yourself as well. You know, our immune systems are really sensitive in reacting to the germs we’re exposed to. When we feel sick, it usually means our immune system is responding and clearing out germs from our nose and throat. But once our immune system is done, we usually go back to feeling normal.
Felix: Oh yeah I remember that from class. But what does this have to do with stress and the cortisol hormone?

Prof. Nassir: It’s actually really interesting, cortisol is really important in our immune system. Turns out, cortisol stops the immune response and helps it return to a normal state. This is usually when people stop feeling sick.
Felix: But then in stressed people? My cortisol levels are so high…

Prof. Nassir: Honestly I’m not really sure what happens when you have high levels of cortisol for a long time, but I do know that people who are stressed and have higher levels of cortisol also tend to feel sick more often..
Felix: Hmm. I feel like that doesn’t really make sense. If cortisol stops the immune response and makes you feel less sick, why would high levels of cortisol make people feel sick for longer?
Prof. Nassir: You know, I’m not entirely sure.
[At that moment, a student of Professor Nassir knocked on the door]

Prof. Nassir: Felix I’m so sorry. I have to meet with Kareem now. (Professor Nasir points at the student waiting at the door). How about this though, I know of this simulator that might be helpful. Why don’t you take a look at it and see if you can figure it out? I’ll email you the link?
Felix: Oh thank you so much! I really appreciate you helping me out!
Felix really liked Prof. Nassir, she cared about her students and how they were doing. He looked down at the report in his hand. He planned to read it after his double shift, when he got home.

text: CHAPTER 5: JOSUÉ’S SOLUTION

The report helped Felix piece the story together. He now understood what was happening to him. Josué was right all along, stress was making him sick. Now the question was what on Earth could he do about it?

That evening while relaxing on the couch with Josué, Felix told him everything he figured out. He expected Josué to be smug with satisfaction that he won this argument. Josué wasn’t. Instead, he handed him his phone.

tiles.title: Felix with Josue using a stress app

text: Josué: Look I found this app called “InsightTimer” that can help you. It’s a meditation app that can help you relax. I looked at a bunch of them and this is the best rated. I tried it too and it is really easy to use. Please, just try it.
Felix: You found this for me?
Josué: Of course I did, mi amor. I care about you!

Josué gave him one of his sarcastic half smiles, the one that was both sweet and annoying at the same time. It was good to know Josué always had his back. Felix downloaded the app and tried it out. The app guided him through a series of meditations and breathing exercises. Every time he used it, he felt like he could breathe a little easier and the heavy feeling in his chest would go away for a bit. As he kept it up regularly, Felix began to notice himself sniffling a lot less. He still got sick more often than Josué, but not as often as before he started using the app. His health was better, but still not 100%.
Felix: Remember how I said I was going to make more time for myself to do some stuff that I love.
Josué: Yeah
Felix: Well, I haven’t played guitar in a while and I really used to love it.
Josué: Of course I remember. You played for me on our first date, remember? It was so cheesy but cute.
Felix: Rude. (Josué laughs) Well anyway, I decided to join the guitar club.
Josué: Isn’t Camila in one of those?
Felix: Yeah! She’s actually the one that told me about it. The people who started the movie club also started this. So it just feels like such a safe space.
Josué: That’s so great!
Felix: I know right? I’m so excited, I couldn’t wait to tell you!
They both laugh, enjoying the light heartedness they felt from knowing Felix was taking steps in the right direction towards a healthier lifestyle.
The End!
• Use your evidence table to develop a model that shows how long-term stress can result in feeling sick more often.
